With a large amount of non-OPEC, US, China and Russian production at the marginal end of the cost curve, OPEC will struggle to martial the cost curve until this production disappears. They *did* modify the quota, in two ways. Firstly, they did a technical raise to 31.5 mbd, to accommodate the actual production (was previously 30 mbd). Secondly, they declared that they're going to do away with a specific quota announcement in the future. This question should probably be closed.

A cartel is only a cartel when it can act as a cartel.  What we are seeing here is cartel dissolution, possibly temporary, but dissolution nonetheless. Global oil production will overwhelm demand for another year or two.  Much of it comes from sources that are beyond OPEC control.  The essence of this question was whether desperate OPEC members like Venezuela could force a Saudi production cut to achieve a reduction in the OPEC production quota.  The Saudis will not budge (see my comment of Oct 23).  Since no other OPEC country is willing to cut production, the cartel now stands in ruins.  The argument and the essence of the question was never about whether to increase the OPEC production.  Given the current supply/demand context, that would be nonsensical.  Failure to maintain or reduce the production quota, is simply failure.  When a cartel cannot reach an effective agreement to limit production and control prices, it is no longer a functioning entity.  Sifting through the wreckage misses this reality.  OPEC no longer has the capacity to change any production quota.  That's just gone.

Well I guess I better update this one. Technically the answer is 0%. OPEC announced no official changes. I am not counting the rejoing of Indonesia as I don't feel this was the spirit of the question. I never expected them to decrease production to begin with. However, the last meeting cemented my opinion that OPEC has dissolved by all means but name only: OPEC cannot enforce its own quotas, OPEC has no collective pricing power, and OPEC is politcally divided to the point of paralysis. So my answer is that the real world production of OPEC is going to increase in 2016 as member states throw off all pretense of limiting production. It is a classic endurance race to the bottom :)

There's nothing in OPEC statute about productions quotas, and, given the history of OPEC resolutions, I'm inclined to agree with @redacted and @Anneinak (discussions: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/55636 http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/55913 ): any quota is in place only as long as there is a consensus among OPEC members to maintain it (or at least to pretend to maintain it), and such consensus is formalized by a resolution (which, by statute, has to be adopted unanimously).

My thinking on this is as follows. They have this central issue that needs to be addressed in some way, at least symbolically:
• Current nominal group "production ceiling:" 30 million bpd*
• Actual group production (including Indonesia): 33 million bpd
• Symbolic imbalance: 3 million bpd (This is a credibility imbalance.)

Think the technical aspect of this question is key: "..establishment or modification of country specific quotas will count.." The key here is Indonesia, rejoining after a 7 year hiatus, and adding some 900k bpd to output. That raises production for the 12+1 group to a little over 32mm bpd (31.38mm bpd last month ex Indonesia). So, even barring a technical adjustment of the 30mm bpd ceiling, it seems almost certain that there would be some minor modification of country specific quotas (especially considering that Iran may deviate some 400k between the lower & upper bounds of expected production). Add to this, the recent announcement of investments by Saudi Aramco to upgrade Indonesia's largest refinery (http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/26/saudi-aramco-indonesia-pertamina-idUSL3N13L42X20151126#uRy4UCM2tJgwEIxD.97) suggests to me that some modification of country specific quotas are in the cards.

What the references below show  are that Saudi Arabia is in this for the long haul. Saudi Arabia knows that shale is a very dangerous technology for them in terms of losing economic dominance over the oil trade, and they intend to knock it out. Like an aggressive cancer,  though,  shale has been more resilient that first thought and the rigs continue to pump strong. In addition,  new technology is beginning to make the break even points of shale decline. In other words,  new technology is making shale increasingly efficient. To counteract this,  Saudi Arabia is not only going to keep prices low,  it's going to have to pump more oil than ever before.  Likewise, in an attempt to stop some of the economic hemorrhaging the country is currently facing, Saudi Arabia will produce more oil in an  attempt to recoup some loses via increased market share.

Per https://www.rt.com/business/236055-us-not-saudi-arabia/ non-OPEC countries accounted for ~56% of oil exports in 2013. Assuming the figures haven't changed too much, it follows that any quotas imposed on OPEC as a collective or individual OPEC countries would have little impact on the price of oil. Any changes drastic enough to have an impact on world oil prices would have a similar (and less tolerable) effect on revenue. However, Indonesia is set to re-join OPEC this December 4 (http://www.cnbc.com/2015/09/08/opec-says-indonesia-to-reactive-its-membership-at-dec-meeting.html). Although it would account for only 3% of OPEC production, the event would provide a reason for a minor adjustment (e.g. to increase the total OPEC quota by median Indonesian production).

Maintaining forecast at 5%. Per Article 11(c) of the OPEC statute (see below), all OPEC decisions require the unanimous agreement of all its members. I just don't see OPEC as being able to coalesce around a change to the overall quote OR a modification of country specific quotas. Some OPEC states, like Iran, would like to see the overall quota bumped up (to make room for production they have coming online), while other smaller OPEC states have urged a cuts to production to boost oil's market price (and help them fill budget gaps). Given these two contradictory positions, unanimity seems unlikely.

The bulk of the OPEC nations are too reliant on the income from oil, and most of them are involved in an expensive war in one sense or another.  None of the countries could afford the cut with the exception of perhaps Saudi Arabia.  And even then, I do not see this happening given the proxy war with Iran in Yemen.  Saudi Arabia can manage a low price far better than Iran, and I see this potentially as a form of economic warfare.  Furthermore, the rest of OPEC often follows the whims of Saudi Arabia since it is the largest oil producer in OPEC.  Lastly, the success of both fracking and recovery from oil sands in the U. S. and Canada poses an existential crisis for OPEC.  The U. S. is one of OPECs best customers and an increase in the price of oil will only aid further development of the domestic oil industry thereby reducing American reliance on OPEC.  The only hope for OPEC in that case is to shift its focus to China.  But that is also a non-starter at the moment given the relative sluggishness of the Chinese economic growth.

Almost certainly not.  Global supply-demand relationships favor continued weakness in oil prices going forward through 2017.  OPEC doesn't have the juice that it once did.  There are too many new sources of production on line, or coming on line.  Saudi Arabia would have a big say in any OPEC production change.  The Saudis need to buy domestic tranquility with public spending.  They have burned through $80 billion in foreign reserves this past year to do that.  They would actually need $100 oil to balance their books on a current basis.  So for the moment, Saudi Arabia's  best choice is not to give up market share by cutting its own production.  Saudi Arabia has $650 billion in foreign reserves left, so it can sustain itself for another 8.2 years.  During the oil glut of the 1980's, the Saudis cut capital spending, kept the dole going, and were very patient.

There has been no clarification of whether adding Indonesia to OPEC would trigger a "yes" resolution. If Indonesia rejoins OPEC soon, as expected in December, then as a formality there will be an adjustment in OPEC's overall production ceiling to account forthis. While this is merely an accounting adjustment rather than a change in production ceilings for any individual OPEC members, we now have to decide how the people who will score this question intend to act. I've decided now that resolving a yes answer on the basis of a technicality would enrage too many players for the comfort of the scorers. Therefore, given the complexity and rarity of changing individual quotas, I'm lowering probability to 0%.

While this is merely an accounting adjustment rather than a change in production ceilings for any individual OPEC members, we now have to decide how the people who will score this question intend to act. I've decided now that resolving a yes answer on the basis of a technicality would enrage too many players for the comfort of the scorers. Therefore, given the complexity and rarity of changing individual quotas, I'm lowering probability to 0%.

OPEC has maintained and exceeded its production targets to guard its share of the market, amid competition from other global players including US shale oil producers.  As for the powerful Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) it is in a relatively strong financial position, because of Saudi Arabia, as illustrated this summer by its decision to maintain high production for long-term gain even though global oil prices were low. Fuel subsidies and tax reforms will likely be among the first issues tackled by some within the GCC, as early as 2016 if oil prices remain low (i.e., Saudi output is increasingly being directed to its domestic market rather than to foreign consumers). Iran may very well prove to be a model of some of these changes, implementing a fixed cash payment system to help manage society's frustration with shrinking subsidies. Ultimately, the Gulf states are unlikely to try and institute long-term changes to state subsidization schemes soon, especially as they deal with unrest in Syria and Yemen and manage the emerging relationship between the United States and Iran.

China's recent correction and a looming chance at a drawn out economic slowdown worldwide should be putting the pressure on OPEC to cut back production soon. They have a short window, between a US Shale collapse and their own collapse, in which to cut production back. Even though OPEC has repeatedly said that their strategy has not been about pushing US Shale and other new producers out of the market, their strategy appears to be working (http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-06-08/america-s-shale-oil-boom-grinding-to-halt-as-u-s-forecasts-drop), so a change could be coming in the next year. Will it come in the next 3 months? No: Iran is probably chomping at the bit to gather market share, Venezuela doesn't have enough sway in OPEC (as we saw last year) to change the production quota, and Saudi Arabia still seems very confident in its ability to survive for even a long period of time on low prices (http://www.bbc.com/news/business-34168659). They have opened up their markets to more investment and are cutting public works projects to balance the budget, but not even considering lower quotas.

I'll go with the crowd for this question.  The current production quota has been stable since December 2011, and there seem to be few indications that Saudi Arabia is interested in changing it.  An even lower estimate would be appropriate but for recent oil price volatility,

The Saudis have two compelling reasons to raise production, and lower the price of oil.  One is that the US is on the brink of out-producing them, and the other is to undercut any competition from the Iranians.  President Obama had removed the knee-jerk support for all things Saudi and Israeli with his Iran deal, and those two unlikely bedfellows are finding that sharing the same creche isn't such a bad idea.   Fracking is is only competitive if prices are high.

With the Saudi King in Washington ostensibly to "be reassured about the Iran nuclear deal," the Saudi are not going to allow prices to increase just as the Iranians are having some sanctions lifted. This is one of the best ways the Saudis can control the Iranians and they are unlikely to give up that control in the near future.

Hmmm. Starting with a mathematical model, I weighted my prediction against the outcome. 
The last (scheduled) OPEC meeting before the January deadline will be held in December. Under normal conditions, this would be a question of supply and demand. Supply far exceeds demand; as it did when the Saudis elected to keep the quota unchanged in 2015. What, if anything, has changed? 
-The US continues to bolster production and pursue alternative energy sources, despite OPEC's driving prices through the floor. 
-In the US, one of OPECS largest/most loyal customers is the US. 2016 is an election year. Reduced dependence on foreign crude will remain a hot-button, as it provides fodder for stump speeches. Americans are particularly responsive to tough talk; and in a field crowded with candidates, with no clear front-runner, the fourth quarter 2015 will be a time for stumping and much podium pounding. A spike in per barrel prices will inflame the drive for US oil production to stay in business, despite profit drains. Therefore, it  is in the interest of all OPEC member countries to keep prices low; i.e, at or near quota.
Saudi Arabia and its allies in the region and the United States, England, and other EU (if not necessarily all NATO) countries want oil priced low for as long as possible.
I'm hesitant to go full 'yes' at this point.

Unlikely.  Saudi Arabia is the big power in OPEC and the Saudis can make a profit well below other oil producing countries.  Also, Saudi Arabia can diminish Iranian revenue and influence at lower price points.  Finally, with lower prices heavy and shale oil fields are not profitable. Strangling heavy and shale oil production is in Saudi interest.
Next OPEC meeting is December 4th in Vienna. That means this question will actually resolve before Jan 1st.

OPEC is currently exceeding its overall production quota by a substantial margin. It may be that OPEC could announce stricter compliance to the quota, but I don't see a change in the quota itself. Saudi Arabia appears determined to continue pumping excess oil in an attempt to hold or increase market share compared to Iran and Iraq (in addition to non-OPEC countries), though it can't say this officially and justifies the action to other OPEC members , less able to sustain low prices, by saying the more expensive non-OPEC producers need to be driven out of the market first.

My low forecast reflects my understanding that OPEC hasn't had individual production quotas since 2011. Instead, it has a group output target. http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/28/business/international/opec-leaves-oil-production-quotas-unchanged-and-prices-fall-further.html?_r=0  As the NYT observed last November, "Restoring quotas is likely to be a lengthy and difficult exercise because the quotas are matters of prestige and economic power."
